TopicTitle: Why does the Wheesley engine work without fuel?

Articles.Content:
I created a plane powered by two Wheesley engines attached to engine nacelles (craft file). I was going to be traveling a ways so I added some fuel tanks as well, but I didn't realize there had to be fuel lines to route the fuel to the engines. I'd already launched when I noticed this, so I thought oh well I'll keep going until the nacelles run out anyways.

Much to my surprise the plane kept flying even with the engine nacelles empty and with the fuel gauge showing a steady 800 units of liquid fuel left. It seems like the plane slowed down at that point (to ~170 m/s) but I don't understand why the engines kept working at all with no fuel. Am I missing something?

Here are the plugins I have installed in case they're relevant somehow:

  • KerbalAlarmClock
  • Docking Port Alignment Indicator
  • KerbalEngineer
  • EditorExtensions
  • WaypointManager

 

Edited March 11, 2016 by Anonymous Kerman
The jet engines don't require fuel lines since they drain in stage not stack.
While its true that jet engines drain fuel from everywhere on the craft without fuel lines, its the materials bay which causes the observed behaviour. It causes the engines to run without fuel.

3 hours ago, rudi1291 said:

While its true that jet engines drain fuel from everywhere on the craft without fuel lines, its the materials bay which causes the observed behaviour. It causes the engines to run without fuel.

If that's true, it makes my career games a lot easier, until 1.1
Okay so this is indeed a bug then. Thanks.
Yeah, i guess it will be fixed soon, since its known: http://bugs.kerbalspaceprogram.com/issues/5909

4 hours ago, rudi1291 said:

While its true that jet engines drain fuel from everywhere on the craft without fuel lines, its the materials bay which causes the observed behaviour. It causes the engines to run without fuel.

Why in the world would that happen? What is in those material bays anyway?
